shell.title: Introduction to AP Psychology: The Exam

hotspots.hotspot:
Should I guess if I don't know the answer?

Yes. You get a point for every correct answer, but no deduction for wrong answers. If you can eliminate one or more wrong answers, you increase you chance of guessing correctly.

Should I change an answer if I think it is wrong?

Maybe. You should change an answer only if you have a good reason. If you are now confident of another answer, change it. (Be sure to erase the old answer thoroughly.) Don't change the answer just because you lack confidence in your original answer.

hotspot.title: Should I answer easy questions first?

hotspots.hotspot:
Should I skip through the exam, answering easy questions first and coming back to harder ones?

Yes. You will be able to manage your time better, because you know how much time you have left to devote to the tougher questions. However, if you skip a question but forget to skip a place on your bubble answer sheet, you'll be in big trouble. You will waste valuable time renumbering all of your subsequent answer choices.

What else can I do while I practice?

Try to answer the question without looking at the possible answers. If you can do this, then you will be simply confirming what you already know when you look at the answer choices.

scene.credits: (tr)Brand X Pictures/PunchStock, (c)Chris Ryan/OJO Images/Getty Images, (bkgd)Glow Images/Getty Images.
(tr)Brand X Pictures/PunchStock, (c)Commercial Eye/Iconica/Getty Images, (bkgd)Glow Images/Getty Images.
(tr)Brand X Pictures/PunchStock, (1)Commercial Eye/Iconica/Getty Images, (2)Fred Paul/Photographer's Choice FR/Getty Images, (bkgd)Glow Images/Getty Images,

hotspots.hotspot:
Prepare

To answer the FRQs you need to know the vocabulary of psychology, and be able to apply the terms and concepts to real life. Practice explaining the terms and concepts, using real-life examples, to friends who don't take psychology.

Be Strategic

You will want to use your limited time to your best advantage. If you are not confident about answering both questions, spend the majority of your time maximizing your score on the question about which you feel the most confident.

Use Time Wisely

You will probably have 50 minutes to answer two FRQs. In that time, you will want to think about each question, write a short outline for each, write the answers, and review your work.

Read Carefully

If the question asks you to define and apply a term or concept, you must do both or you won't score a point.

If the question asks you to identify a concept in the context of a psychological study, be sure you do so, or you won't score the point.

scene.credits: (tr)Brand X Pictures/PunchStock, (c)Commercial Eye/Iconica/Getty Images, (bkgd)Glow Images/Getty Images.

hotspots.hotspot: For each of the three concepts, you must provide BOTH a definition and an application of it to Joe's situation. If you provide only a definition or only an application, you will not score a point for that concept.

Because you are asked to define and apply three terms, there are a total of three question points available for this question. Since the question is worth 25 points on your exam, each question point is worth 8.33 exam points.

Here, you learn that Section II is worth 33 1/3 percent of your total test grade. That's roughly one third. There are a total of 50 points available in this section of the exam. 25 points for question 1 and 25 points for question 2.

multiple.question: How many points would the student earn on a FRQ in which he was asked to define and apply conformity, extrinsic motivation, and the amygdala?

answers.answer: 8.33 exam points for conformity and none for the other two concepts
8.33 exam points for conformity, and 4.165 for each of the other two concepts

figure.text:
The student was able to include only the following in his essay:
  • The correct definition and application for conformity
  • Only the correct definition for extrinsic motivation
  • Only the correct application for amygdala

multiple.question: Sabrina got 75 questions correct on the multiple choice section of the Exam, and she earned 35 of 50 possible points for the FRQs. What is her raw score and possible grade?

answers.answer: Her raw score is 110, which is probably a 3.
Her raw score is 125, which is probably a 5.
Her raw score is 4, which is equivalent to 96%.
Her raw score is 110, which is probably a 5.
Her raw score is 75 minus 15 wrong points on the FRQs or 60, which is probably a 3.

figure.text:
College Board example cut scores: a score of around 105 and above earn a 5;

a score between around 90 to 105 earns a 4;

a score between around 80 to 90 or 95 earns a 3, and so on.

multiple.question: You have plenty of time to answer the multiple-choice questions. You are only graded on the questions you actually answer.
If you memorize the definitions for terms in psychology, you'll do fine.
It's OK to skip difficult questions and come back to them later.
You must include in your essay opening and concluding paragraphs that summarize your answer.
The FRQs are a minor part of the exam grade. Don't worry much about them.
It helps to write a quick outline of your answer to a free response question before you write your answer.
Get the information down in whatever form you wish to use.
It is never a good idea to guess on a question. You either know it or you don't.
It is never a good idea to change an answer. Your first impression is always the best answer.
It is important to do well on the multiple-choice part of the exam because it is more than half of your final score.
